official-title.#text: To provide for the issuance of coins to commemorate the 100th anniversary of the establishment of the National Park Service, and for other purposes.

attestation-date.#text: Passed the House of Representatives April 29, 2014.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Park Service 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Park Service 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: to administer America’s great national parks and monuments as a unified

text.#text: In 1916, Congress established the National Park Service as a bureau within the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: has grown from 37 park units with 6,000,000 acres of land in the western United States to more than 395 units with 84,000,000 acres of land in nearly all States and territories.

text.#text: From 1916 to the present, the
The responsibilities of the National Park Service have grown to include—
managing national historic trails and national scenic trails;
administering wild and scenic rivers;
recognizing America’s most significant historic resources through the National Register of Historic Places and the National Historic Landmark program;
providing historic preservation grants; and
assisting communities in meeting their preservation, conservation, and recreation needs.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , which established the National Park Service, remains the preeminent law guiding the management of parks and articulating the Service’s core mission,
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: National Park Service Organic Act of 1916
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Park Service Organic Act of 1916

quote.#text: to conserve the scenery and the natural and historic objects and the wild life therein and to provide for the enjoyment of the same in such manner and by such means as will leave them unimpaired for the enjoyment of future generations

text.#text: The

The 100th anniversary of the National Park Service in 2016 will be an occasion to celebrate a century of American vision and achievement in identifying and preserving our Nation’s special places for the benefit of everyone and the culmination of 100 years of accomplishment by the National Park Service’s employees, partners, and volunteers. It will also mark the beginning of the organization’s second century of service to the American people as environmental leaders and vigilant stewards of the Nation’s treasured places and stories.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and to the legacy Congress left in 1916 when it established a Federal agency to ensure the protection of our Nation’s most treasured natural and cultural resources for all time.

text.#text: Coins commemorating the 100th anniversary of the National Park Service will bring national and international attention to the

The proceeds from a surcharge on the sale of commemorative coins will assist the financing of the needs of the National Park Service’s parks and programs, helping to ensure that our Nation’s great natural and cultural resources will endure for generations to come.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: (hereafter in this Act referred to as the

quote.#tail: ) shall mint and issue the following coins:

text.#text: The
Not more than 100,000 $5 coins, which shall—
weigh 8.359 grams;
have a diameter of 0.850 inches; and
contain 90 percent gold and 10 percent alloy.
Not more than 500,000 $1 coins, which shall—
weigh 26.73 grams;
have a diameter of 1.500 inches; and
contain 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper.
Not more than 750,000 half dollar coins, which shall—
weigh 11.34 grams;
have a diameter of 1.205 inches; and
be minted to the specifications for half dollar coins, contained in
The coins minted under this Act shall be legal tender, as provided in

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: and
, all coins minted under this Act shall be considered to be numismatic items.

text.#text: For purposes of
The design of the coins minted under this Act shall be emblematic of the 100th anniversary of the
On each coin minted under this Act there shall be—
a designation of the face value of the coin;
an inscription of the year
inscriptions of the words
The design for the coins minted under this Act shall be—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: after consultation with—

text.#text: selected by the
the
the National Park Foundation; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: ; and

text.#text: the
reviewed by the
Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: may issue coins minted under this Act only during the period beginning on January 1, 2016, and ending on December 31, 2016.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall make bulk sales of the coins issued under this Act at a reasonable discount.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall accept prepaid orders for the coins minted under this Act before the issuance of such coins.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall be at a reasonable discount.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: National Park Service 100th Anniversary Commemorative Coin Act/s:6/ss:c/p:1

text.#text: Sale prices with respect to prepaid orders under
All sales of coins minted under this Act shall include a surcharge as follows:
A surcharge of $35 per coin for the $5 coin.
A surcharge of $10 per coin for the $1 coin.
A surcharge of $5 per coin for the half dollar coin.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , all surcharges which are received by the
from the sale of coins issued under this Act shall be promptly paid by the
to the National Park Foundation for projects and programs that help preserve and protect resources under the stewardship of the
and promote public enjoyment and appreciation of those resources.
